page.lettertext:
There hath bin some troble of late in
e towne of
Bom-
mel
, about
e newe Election of certain popishe Burg-
masters, from whome
e Burgers, of w
ch
e greatest
part are well affected in religion, have taken
e
keies of their office by violence, alleaging
at nether
e Electo
rs
observed
e dewe forme of Election, and
that
e parties elected were frindes to
e Enemie.
Wheruppon they have delivered
e keies to
e olde
Eschevins, and are assisted in all thinges by
e Garri-
son of
e towne. The
Councell
is very carefull
to make a quiet end between them, fearing
e dan-
ger
at may ensewe, if
e Enemie,
at lieth but a
mile from
e towne, should practise, uppon this oppor-
tunitie, w
t
his favourers w
t
in.
I send yo
r
H. heere w
t
a note of certaine occuren-
ces from
Strawesbourgh
, by w
ch
it should seeme
at
e
Lieguers
practise to divert
e forces, w
ch
e Germane
Princes send to
e
Frenche King
, by ministring mater[s]
unto them of imploiment in their owne territories.
W
ch
is all, I trust, for
e best, and will waken
as many in that sleepy contrey, as are any thing
well disposed. There is a mes-
senger newe come from
Berke
to
e Councell of
state, w
t
charge to signifie,
at
e 3 of this mo-
neth a generall partition being made of all
e
victuall and provision in
e towne, there came no
more to every mans share, but for a fortnights
sustenance. Wheruppon
e Deputies of
e
Countesse
of Neuwenar
urge to have an answer, w
ch
they
have not yet receaved. Some men heere, that
consider
e povertie of
e Countesse, and
e disposi-
tion of her nature, suspect that she hath no mea-
ning to make
e towne Neutrall, nor should not,
if she would, obtene it of
e Enemie: but if
it were in her possession, she would surrender it
in exchaunge of some of those Principalities whiche
the Enemie holdeth from her.
Ja
n
12. 89
